content: Cellular senescence is characterized by a permanent state of cell cycle arrest accompanied by a secretory phenotype. Research has shown that senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to age-related pathologies. Senolytics are a class of drugs designed to selectively eliminate senescent cells, potentially alleviating age-related conditions.

The Hallmarks of Aging, published in Cell in 2013 by López-Otín et al., established a framework of nine hallmarks: genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, loss of proteostasis, deregulated nutrient sensing, mitochondrial dysfunction, cellular senescence, stem cell exhaustion, and altered intercellular communication. This framework has been instrumental in organizing research on aging mechanisms and potential interventions.

NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) levels decline with age, and this decline is associated with various aspects of aging. Supplementation with NAD+ precursors like NMN (nicotinamide mononucleotide) and NR (nicotinamide riboside) has shown promise in restoring NAD+ levels and improving certain physiological parameters in animal studies.

Studies in model organisms including yeast, worms, flies, and mice have consistently shown that caloric restriction extends lifespan. The mechanisms involve signaling pathways such as mTOR, AMPK, and sirtuins, which sense nutrient availability and regulate cellular processes including autophagy, stress response, and metabolism.

Rapamycin, an inhibitor of the mTOR pathway, has been shown to extend lifespan in multiple model organisms. Clinical trials are exploring its potential benefits for age-related diseases and conditions. Challenges include managing side effects and developing optimal dosing strategies for human use.
